| ;4 a CONVERSATION WITH JACKIE ROBINSON THIS PROBLEM
OF SELF-IMAGE WAS TAKEN OUT OF THE CLINIC OR LABOR¬
ATORY, AND WE LEARNED HOW ONE YOUNGSTER HAD TO FACE
THIS NEGATIVE EVALUATION, AND HOW HIS PARENTS COPED
WITH THE PROBLEM.
I THINK THE THING THAT AWAKENED ME MORE THAN ANY¬
THING WAS WHEN WE FIRST MOVED UP TO STANFORD, CONN¬
ECTICUT. There wasn’t anything vicious about this
INCIDENT, BUT MY LITTLE BOY, MY YOUNGEST ONE, CAME
HOME ONE DAY FROM SCHOOL, AND HE SEEMED EXTRAORDIN¬
ARILY QUIET, AND SOMETHING HAPPENED AT SCHOOL WHERE
SOMEBODY HAD KIDDED HIM ABOUT THE COLORING OF HIS
SKIN...CALLED HIM DIRTY, OR SOMETHING, AND HE WAS
DEEPLY HURT BY IT. AND WHEN WE FOUND OUT WHAT IT
WAS, IT CERTAINLY MADE US THINK, AND WE STOPPED AN
TALKED TO HIM AND EXPLAINED THAT IF HE LOOKED AT
THE COLORING OF HIS MOTHER AND HIS FATHER, AND IF
HAD THE SAME KIND OF PRIDE THAT WE HAVE IN THE FACi
THAT WE ARE MADE AS WE ARE. ..THAT GOD HAD GIVEN US
THIS SKIN BECAUSE THIS WAS WHAT HE WANTED US TO HA\
THEN HE SHOULDN’T FEEL BADLY ABOUT IT, AND REGARD¬
LESS OF WHAT PEOPLE SAY OR DO, FOR HIM NOT TO EVER
WORRY ABOUT IT BECAUSE NAMES CANNOT HURT HIM. ^ND
HE HAD SIMILAR EXPERIENCES LATER ON, AND HE HAS
REALLY COME THROUGH FINE WITH FLYING COLORS.
In his story, ivir, Robinson suggests to us the posss
BILITY OF A CONFLICT IN SELF-IMAGES. THE 30Y WAS
GIVEN ONE IMAGE AT SCHOOL AND ABOTHER BY HIS PAREN'
This conflictis actually more than a possibility.
It represents something very real. Let’s take a
CLOSE LOOK AT CONFLICT IN SELF-IMAGES, AND NOTE Wh
IT DOES TO THE INDIVIDUAL. 'J E MIGHT BEGIN BY ASSU
|NG A SOCIETY IN WHICH THE FACT OF COLOR DIFFERENCE
WAS ABSOLUTELY MEANINGLESS TO PEOPLE. AND IN WHIG
THEREFORE, YOUNG ROBINSONS WOULD NEVER BE TOLD AT
SCHOOL THAT THEY WERE DIRTY BECAUSE THEY WERE COL¬
ORED. In such a case the self-image of the Negro
CHILD WOULD NOT DIFFER, BECAUSE HE WAS NEGRO* FROM
THAT OF A WHITE CHILD. THIS IS A SITUATION WHICH,
TO PUT IT CONSERVATIVELY, WE HAVE HARDLY REACHED.
:} £ MIGHT ALSO CONCEIVE A VERY DIFFERENT SITUATION
IN WHICH ALL WHITE JUDGEMENTS OF ALL NEGROES WERE
DISTINCTLY UNFAVORABLE. INEVITABLY, NEGROES WOULD
INCORPORATE MUCH OF THE UNFAVORABLY TINGED ATTITUD
TOWARD THEMSELVES OF THE WHITES. If THERE WERE, I
THIS CASE, ANY FAVORABLE ELEMENTS IN THE SELF-IMAC
of the Negro they would somehow have to be generat
ED WITHIN THE NEGRO GROUP ITSELF, WITH OUT ANY AID
FROM WHITES.
